intro: Calceolaria algarrobensis, commonly known as the Andean hooded orchid, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Andes in South America. It belongs to the family Campanulaceae and is characterized by its unique, hood-like calyces that enclose the flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving in cool, moist conditions. Its flowers are usually violet or purple, with intricate structures that aid in pollination by specific insect species. Calceolaria algarrobensis is valued for its ornamental beauty and is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
